predictions: Zully Broussard's selfless kidney donation initiated a six-person transplant chain, facilitated by a new matching program.  This rare event, enabled by big data and her altruism, highlights the potential of paired donations to save multiple lives.

The MLS, launched in 1996, has significantly grown, boasting increased attendance, more teams, and a lucrative TV deal.  Despite initial struggles and challenges like a salary cap, the league is attracting top talent and aiming for greater prominence in US sports.

Swansea's Gomis collapsed during a match due to low blood pressure, a pre-existing condition.  He's recovering well, though the incident was frightening.  The club was aware of his history of fainting spells before signing him.

Rory McIlroy, frustrated by a bad shot, threw his 3-iron into a lake during the WGC Cadillac Championship.  Despite this, he finished with a 70, but remains eight shots behind leader JB Holmes.  His frustration stems from inconsistencies between his practice and tournament play.

Thirteen-year-old Cayman Naib disappeared in Pennsylvania.  Hundreds are searching, aided by technology and the Civil Air Patrol.  His parents believe he left impulsively after receiving a school email about overdue homework.  They've appealed to him to return home.

Curt Schilling tracked down and exposed Twitter users who sent rape threats to his daughter.  Two perpetrators lost jobs, and Schilling considers legal action.  The incident highlights the need for online accountability and responsible parenting while emphasizing that free speech isn't without limits.

Two American women were arrested in Rome for carving their initials into the Colosseum.  This follows similar incidents involving tourists defacing historical sites in Rome, Egypt, Cambodia, and Peru, highlighting a global problem of disrespectful tourist behavior.

Prince and 3rdEyeGirl's Hit & Run Tour hits the US for the first time in Louisville, KY on March 14th.  Ticket sales begin March 9th, with proceeds benefiting Louisville charities.  The venue remains unannounced.

A shooting at a Bamako bar killed five (including French and Belgian citizens) and wounded eight.  Al-Murabitun, a North African jihadist group, claimed responsibility, citing retaliation for a leader's death.  The attack highlights ongoing conflict in Mali.

Jonny Evans and Papiss Cisse were charged by the FA for allegedly spitting at each other during a Premier League match.  Video evidence led to the charges, despite the referee missing the incident.  Both players deny wrongdoing, but face potential six-game bans.  Pundits condemned the behavior.

The March 10, 2015, CNN Student News covered a solar-powered plane's global circumnavigation attempt, Siberian craters, and a unique Everest view.  The segment also included a transcript and a "Roll Call" for student participation.

ISIS-affiliated militants attacked a Libyan oil field, kidnapping nine foreign workers (including four Filipinos, an Austrian, a Czech, a Ghanaian, and a Bangladeshi).  The attack follows a recent escalation of violence targeting Libyan oil fields.  Authorities are working to secure their release.

Wichita high school principal Sherman Padgett received an unexpected senior prank: students dropped thank-you notes into a bucket, expressing gratitude for his support and positive impact on their lives, leaving him deeply moved.

Norman Lee, a DC and Marvel comic book artist, is presumed dead after a snorkeling accident in Grand Cayman.  Strong currents hampered the search, now a recovery mission, leaving friends and colleagues mourning his loss.

The March 9, 2015, CNN Student News covered the anniversary of the Selma march, the missing Malaysia Airlines flight, and International Women's Day,  analyzed the US unemployment report, and offered a "Roll Call" segment for schools to be featured.  A transcript was available.

Jessie Usher joins Liam Hemsworth and Jeff Goldblum in the "Independence Day" sequel, playing Will Smith's son.  The film, directed by Roland Emmerich, is slated for release June 24, 2016, and marks a significant step for Usher's career.
87-year-old former Vice President Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic after treatment for influenza.  He was admitted following a fever during a routine checkup.  He's recovering well.

Kyle Waring's ShipSnowYo.com sells Boston snow ($89 for 6 lbs) to customers outside New England.  His business, born from a snow-shoveling joke, has filled over 133 orders, capitalizing on Boston's record snowfall.  He plans to expand to other seasonal items.

Syrian, Iraqi, and Palestinian refugee women in Jordan, despite facing poverty, legal barriers, and violence, are building businesses and supporting their families.  Aid agencies must shift from short-term assistance to empowering women with skills, resources, and protection to achieve long-term economic independence.

Real Madrid lost 1-0 to Athletic Bilbao, potentially giving Barcelona the La Liga lead.  Real's lack of offensive efficiency concerns Ancelotti.  Bayern Munich won in the Bundesliga, while PSG leads Ligue 1 temporarily.
Japanese police arrested a 40-year-old man who confessed to stabbing five neighbors to death in Sumoto city.  The victims, two couples and one woman, lived near the suspect, who shared their surname.
A suicide car bombing near a police vehicle in Lashkar Gah, Afghanistan killed seven and injured 23, mostly civilians including children.  The attacker's identity and motive remain unknown.

Pakistan's Supreme Court ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, the alleged mastermind of the 2008 Mumbai attacks, deeming his detention illegal.  India strongly condemned the decision, summoning Pakistan's high commissioner.

A DeKalb County police officer shot and killed an unarmed, naked African-American man who charged at him.  The incident is under investigation by the Georgia Bureau of Investigations, prompted by concerns over police shootings.  The officer, a seven-year veteran, is on leave.

A photo of a weasel riding a woodpecker went viral.  Taken in an Essex park, the amateur photographer captured the brief struggle.  Experts say while unusual, a hungry weasel might attack a woodpecker, though likely unsuccessfully.  The image spawned numerous humorous online parodies.

eBay is flooded with listings selling air allegedly from Kanye West concerts, reaching exorbitant prices despite lacking authenticity.  This follows the release of his Adidas Yeezy Boost sneakers, ironically priced far higher than West intended.

Delta Flight 1086 skidded off LaGuardia's runway due to reported brake failure despite "max" auto-brake setting.  The crew cited poor deceleration and the failure of automatic spoilers to deploy.  Twenty-three passengers sustained minor injuries.  The NTSB is investigating.
Over 100 Pakistani schools have been renamed after the 132 children killed in a Taliban attack on the Army Public School in Peshawar last December, as a tribute to their bravery.
The Salvation Army in South Africa uses the "the dress" viral image, modified to show a bruised model, to raise awareness about domestic violence, highlighting the difficulty in recognizing abuse.

NASCAR reinstated Kurt Busch after his indefinite suspension for alleged domestic violence,  following a Delaware court's decision not to file charges and Busch's completion of a behavioral program.  He remains on indefinite probation.

The MH370 interim report reveals significant delays and communication failures in the initial response to the plane's disappearance.  A lack of urgency and coordination between air traffic control, military radar, and airlines hampered the search, wasting crucial time before search efforts began.
A ferry capsized in Myanmar due to bad weather, killing 21 and leaving 21 missing.  167 were rescued.  This follows a string of fatal ferry accidents in the region, highlighting safety concerns.

Myanmar warplanes bombed a Chinese sugarcane field, killing four and injuring nine.  China responded by sending fighter jets to patrol the border, summoning Myanmar's ambassador, and demanding an investigation.

Self-diagnosing online can be misleading.  Unreliable sources, emotional biases, and forum misinformation are pitfalls.  Use reputable sites (.org, .edu), symptom checkers for guidance, and always share online research with your doctor.  Don't delay professional medical attention.

A Nevada grand jury indicted 19-year-old Erich Nowsch Jr. for murder, attempted murder, and weapons charges in the shooting death of his neighbor, Tammy Meyers.  Nowsch claims self-defense, while police allege a road-rage incident escalated to gunfire.  The driver of the other car remains at large.

Recent racial tensions, highlighted by police shootings and racist incidents, demand improved police-community relations.  Solutions include community policing (foot patrols, bike units),  mediation, and fostering positive interactions to build trust and mutual respect, replacing fear and mistrust.

A North Korean diplomat in Bangladesh was caught smuggling $1 million worth of undeclared gold.  Bangladesh protested, and the diplomat, who apologized, has left the country.  The incident's significance remains unclear.

A Utah toddler, Lily, survived a car crash that killed her mother.  Rescuers found her upside down in the submerged car 14 hours later.  Her father says she's recovering well, and he's incredibly grateful.

Two helicopter crashes occurred this week: an EagleMed helicopter crashed in Oklahoma, with three aboard; and an Army Black Hawk crashed in Florida, killing all 11 service members.  Investigations are underway.

Monohm's Runcible, a circular "anti-smartphone," challenges the rectangular dominance of screens.  Its round form aims to reduce distractions and promote mindful tech use, prompting a reconsideration of how device shape influences interaction and app design.  This reflects a broader trend toward exploring alternative screen shapes and interactions.

The upcoming Star Wars novel, "Lords of the Sith," introduces Moff Mors, the franchise's first officially gay character—a lesbian Imperial official.  This marks a significant inclusion within Disney's approved Star Wars canon.

Suicide bombers attacked a Lahore church, killing at least 14 and wounding 78.  The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility, vowing further attacks until Sharia law is implemented.  The attack follows a recent reunification of the group and highlights ongoing persecution of religious minorities in Pakistan.

A massive IRS impersonation scam has defrauded over 3,000 victims of more than $15 million since 2013.  Scammers, likely based in India, use stolen information and convincing tactics to pressure victims into paying thousands of dollars to avoid fabricated legal trouble.  Hanging up is the best response.

Republican efforts to undermine Obama's Iran policy, while seemingly extraordinary, pale in comparison to past partisan actions by both Democrats and Republicans,  demonstrating a long history of politicized foreign policy that challenges executive authority.

Pope Francis, in a recent interview, expects a short papacy (4-5 years),  comparing it to a gambler's mindset.  He enjoys his role but misses anonymity and plans a "Jubilee of Mercy."  He also stated that spanking children is acceptable if not demeaning.

Ashton Kutcher's Facebook post highlighting the lack of baby changing tables in men's restrooms sparked a debate about parental equality.  Many parents supported his point, emphasizing the need for better facilities for dads and families with two dads.  The post generated significant online discussion.

Spain's "world's most dangerous path," Caminito del Rey, reopens March 26 after a €5.5 million reconstruction.  The renovated cliffside walkway, initially built for hydroelectric workers, offers stunning views but requires advance booking.  Entry is free for the first six months.

Isaac Herzog, leading in pre-election polls, aims to become Israel's next Prime Minister.  He emphasizes social justice, cooperation with world powers on Iran, and restarting peace talks with the Palestinians, contrasting his collaborative style with Netanyahu's.

Hundreds of thousands of Brazilians protested President Rousseff's alleged inaction regarding a massive Petrobras corruption scandal, amid a struggling economy.  While Rousseff hasn't been implicated, protesters demand her impeachment, fueled by public perception of her accountability.  Further protests are planned.

Sixteen Indonesian citizens, including children, were detained in Turkey for planning to enter Syria.  A separate group of sixteen Indonesians also went missing in Turkey, possibly entering Syria. Indonesia is investigating both incidents.

Crude bombs were thrown at a Tamil news station in India after it planned a show on the mangalsutra necklace, angering Hindu groups.  This incident highlights India's struggle with free speech,  demonstrated by censorship and protests against films, books, and documentaries deemed offensive.

In 2001, Serena Williams faced racial abuse at Indian Wells after her sister withdrew from the tournament.  This led to a 14-year boycott, but Serena is returning, seeking closure and a warm reception, though her family remains divided.

A new mobile app from Kick It Out has increased reporting of racist and other abusive behavior in English football by 35%, leading to more investigations and sanctions.  Video evidence, like that from the Paris metro incident, is proving particularly effective.

Lisa Green argues parents should proactively seek legal counsel for their teens,  given the potential for swift and severe legal consequences, even for seemingly minor infractions.  She emphasizes knowing teens' rights and understanding relevant laws, including social host laws and school policies, to better guide and protect them.

Photographer Ignacio Evangelista documents abandoned European border checkpoints, remnants of the pre-Schengen era.  His "After Schengen" project showcases the ghostly architecture of these former control points, highlighting the transformation of European travel and the lingering atmosphere of past border controls.

Formula One driver Daniel Ricciardo reflects on his 2014 Australian Grand Prix disqualification due to a fuel flow violation.  Despite past mechanical failures and disappointments, he's eager for redemption at his home race, emphasizing the sport's unforgiving nature and reliance on both driver skill and machine performance.

Disney's live-action "Cinderella" debuted strongly, exceeding expectations with $70.1 million, outperforming "Maleficent."  Liam Neeson's "Run All Night" underwhelmed, while "It Follows" impressed in limited release.  "Kingsman: The Secret Service" continued its success.

Harper Lee's upcoming book, "Go Set a Watchman," faces questions about her consent at age 88.  An Alabama investigation concluded she understood and wanted publication, closing the case.  The book, written before "To Kill a Mockingbird," is still scheduled for July release.

A photo of a sailor holding his baby in an American flag sparked debate.  Some viewed it as patriotic, representing service and family, while others considered it a flag desecration, citing the U.S. Flag Code.  The photographer, a Navy veteran, defended the image.

Candida Moss answers viewer questions about CNN's "Finding Jesus" series.  Key topics include the significance of the number 40 in the Bible, the relationship between Jesus and John the Baptist's followers, DNA evidence related to Jesus's lineage, and extra-biblical sources confirming John the Baptist's existence.

Smartwatches offer convenience, but lead to compulsive checking ("phantom device effect"), privacy concerns due to data collection, and an unhealthy obsession with personal wellness, potentially replacing social interaction with self-monitoring.

Robert Durst, charged with the 2000 murder of Susan Berman, had his Houston home raided.  The raid follows his arrest in New Orleans, where he faces weapons and drug charges.  His attorney claims the actions are a result of the HBO documentary "The Jinx."

The Southern Poverty Law Center reports a 17% decrease in US hate groups since 2013, reaching their lowest levels since 2005.  This decline, attributed to various factors including economic recovery and the high social cost of affiliation, is partially offset by a rise in online hate and lone-wolf extremism.

Renowned preacher Fred Craddock died at 86.  Known for his unique, conversational sermon style and compassionate nature, he profoundly impacted preaching and was lauded for his storytelling ability and personal warmth.  His funeral is Monday.

The State Department only recently began automatically archiving high-level officials' emails, raising questions about Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server.  Republicans demand access to Clinton's server, while Clinton claims she emailed government officials to ensure preservation.  The State Department acknowledges past record-keeping imperfections.

Ten American aid workers, exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone, returned to the US for monitoring.  One developed symptoms and was hospitalized; others remain asymptomatic.  The infected colleague is in critical condition at NIH.  Monitoring varies by location, with some workers under stricter isolation than others.

Arsenal defeated Manchester United 2-1 in the FA Cup quarterfinals at Old Trafford.  Welbeck scored the winner against his former club, while Di Maria was sent off for grabbing the referee.  Arsenal advances to the semifinals.

A US Justice Department investigation revealed Ferguson, Missouri's, police and court system systematically targeted African-American residents with excessive fines for revenue, not public safety.  This caused hardship for residents like Loistine Hoskin, who lost her car and $1200 in fines.  Ferguson is implementing reforms.

Amidst health speculation following canceled appearances, Putin's Kremlin released photos showing him meeting with the Supreme Court head.  His spokesperson dismissed rumors as "spring fever," assuring Putin's health.  Upcoming meetings were announced.

PSG, despite Ibrahimovic's red card, beat Chelsea in the Champions League Round of 16 on away goals after a dramatic extra-time comeback fueled by Thiago Silva's redemption.  Bayern Munich also advanced, crushing Shakhtar Donetsk 7-0.

Five Chelsea fans face court for racist abuse of a black man on the Paris Metro before a Champions League match.  Video evidence showed them preventing him from boarding and chanting racist slurs.  Chelsea condemned the actions, and the fans face potential life bans and football banning orders.

Sotheby's is auctioning Maurizio Cattelan's black granite sculpture detailing every England football team defeat from 1874-1998 for $900,000.  The artist describes it as representing "pride, missed opportunities, and death."

Tens of thousands protested in Tel Aviv, demanding Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu's removal due to dissatisfaction with his handling of a two-state solution and the cost of living.  The rally, while not endorsing specific candidates, mirrors a 2011 movement calling for broader societal change.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 30th annual induction ceremony will feature performances by Beck and John Legend, and inductions by Paul McCartney, Patti Smith, and others, airing on HBO May 30th.  Seven artists/groups will be inducted.

A US Air Force veteran, Tairod Pugh, pleaded not guilty to charges of attempting to support ISIS.  Turkish authorities stopped him from entering Syria in January.  Evidence included a letter expressing his intent to join ISIS and jihadist propaganda on his devices.  He faces up to 35 years in prison.

Silicon Valley's tech boom isn't creating good jobs, instead replacing them with low-wage or unstable "gig" work, harming millennials and threatening a widening wealth gap.  Holding Silicon Valley accountable is crucial to prevent a dystopian future.

The wreck of the CSS Georgia is being salvaged to deepen Savannah's shipping channel.  Initial artifacts include leg irons, cannons, and personal items, offering glimpses into life aboard the Confederate ironclad, which was scuttled in 1864.  Further excavation aims to reveal more about the crew's experiences.

New Zealanders are seizing keys from foreign drivers due to dangerous driving, causing eight deaths in two weeks.  Authorities condemn this vigilante justice, citing legal gray areas and advocating for improved driver education and road signage instead.  The issue is particularly acute in tourist-heavy regions.

Tropical Cyclone Pam, a powerful Category 4 storm, devastated Vanuatu, causing widespread destruction and leaving many homeless.  Urgent needs include shelter, food, and water.  The storm weakened after landfall but still poses a threat to nearby islands and New Zealand.

Despite Iran's hostility towards Israel, Esfahan's Jewish community, numbering around 1,500, openly practices its faith.  They feel integrated into Iranian society, differentiating themselves from Israeli Jews and prioritizing peace over geopolitical tensions.  Concerns from friends abroad exist, but the community feels safe and at home.

Israel's upcoming elections offer minimal policy differences between Netanyahu and Herzog, particularly regarding the Palestinian occupation.  Both candidates avoid addressing this central issue, focusing instead on domestic matters and scandals, leaving the Palestinians' fate largely ignored.

A Turkish TV network released a video purportedly showing three British schoolgirls near the Turkey-Syria border, believed to be en route to join ISIS.  The video's authenticity is unconfirmed, but it follows reports of a foreign agent's arrest for allegedly assisting their travel.

Kerry Washington will star in and executive produce HBO's "Confirmation," a TV movie about the 1991 Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill Supreme Court hearings.  Susannah Grant will write, and Rick Famuyiwa may direct.

Forty-seven Republican senators' letter to Iran, interfering with Obama's nuclear negotiations, exemplifies a pattern of profound disrespect towards the president, fueled by both explicit and implicit racial bias, exceeding typical political disagreements.

A CNN journalist interviewed Prince Charles at Birkhall, his Scottish home,  for a special on his and Camilla's 10-year marriage and upcoming US tour.  Camilla declined an interview but allowed filming during public appearances.  The journalist found the couple close and happy.

A UVA student's bloody arrest by alcohol control agents sparked protests and a campus forum with police.  The incident, under investigation, involved allegations of police brutality against a Black student, prompting calls for justice and raising concerns about racial bias in policing.

Kelly Gissendaner, on death row, underwent profound spiritual transformation through theological studies and pastoral support.  Her journey, marked by remorse and hope, challenges the limits of Christian faith and forgiveness, prompting calls for clemency.

Watertown police officers recounted an eight-minute shootout with the Boston Marathon bombing suspects.  Tamerlan Tsarnaev died after being run over by his brother, Dzhokhar, who escaped but was later apprehended.  The trial showcased the intense gun battle and Dzhokhar's boat, containing incriminating messages.

Eleven service members died in a Black Hawk helicopter crash during a training mission in Florida.  The search and rescue operation has transitioned to recovery efforts.  The cause of the crash, which occurred in heavy fog, is under investigation.

A terrorist attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum killed 23, mostly foreign tourists.  Two gunmen, identified as Yassine Labidi and Saber Khachnaou, were killed by security forces. ISIS claimed responsibility, and investigations are ongoing, with nine arrests made.  The attack's aftermath includes repatriation of victims and ongoing hospitalizations.

Following a DOJ report exposing systemic racism, Ferguson's police chief and city manager resigned.  Residents are now attempting to recall Mayor Knowles, citing his failure to address police misconduct, while others defend his efforts at reform.  Two officers were also shot during a protest.

Ozgecan Aslan's murder sparked widespread protests in Turkey, highlighting the country's high rates of violence against women.  Her father plans to use donations to create a rehabilitation center for male abusers, focusing on love and change rather than revenge.  The case mirrors India's 2012 bus rape case, both revealing deep-seated gender inequality.

Lindsey Vonn won her record-breaking 65th World Cup victory in super-G, boosting her chances for end-of-season titles despite trailing in the overall standings.  Kjetil Jansrud secured the men's Super-G title.  The season concludes with finals in France.

The article highlights the pervasive issue of child sex trafficking in the US, citing harrowing examples and advocating for two bills: the JVTA, which supports victims and strengthens law enforcement, and the SETT, which encourages states to implement "safe harbor" laws protecting child victims from prosecution.

Following a deadly attack on a Tunisian museum, a social media campaign, "#IWillComeToTunisia," aims to bolster the nation's tourism industry, vital to its economy.  Users express solidarity and defiance, countering travel warnings with pledges to visit.

Former Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli is considering a comeback to professional tennis after retiring due to injury in 2013.  Her decision is prompting debate, with some advising full commitment.  Several other female stars have successfully returned after retirement.

Liza Minnelli, 68, has entered rehab for substance abuse, according to her spokesman.  This follows past struggles with alcohol and painkillers.  She's reportedly making good progress at an undisclosed facility.

Zaur Dadayev, the main suspect in Boris Nemtsov's murder, recanted his confession, claiming coercion.  Two human rights activists who interviewed him face charges, prompting Amnesty International's condemnation.  Other suspects also deny involvement.

Ferguson, Missouri, seeks a new police chief to rebuild community trust shattered after the Michael Brown shooting.  The ideal candidate will need empathy, confidence, and a commitment to reforming the department's culture, mirroring Sanford, Florida's successful approach after the Trayvon Martin case.  Finding the best candidate, regardless of race, is crucial.

March Madness, the NCAA Tournament, pits college basketball powerhouses against underdogs, offering a platform for aspiring NBA players.  The tournament's popularity and exposure significantly impact players' professional prospects, even those from smaller programs, as demonstrated by success stories like Stephen Curry.  Selection Sunday determines seeding for the 68-team knockout tournament.

Google CFO Patrick Pichette's resignation, lauded for prioritizing family, highlights the unattainable "work-life balance" ideal.  His privileged position allows early retirement; most lack this luxury.  The article criticizes corporate culture for demanding constant availability, hindering true balance.

A.J. Pero, Twisted Sister's longtime drummer, died at 55 from an apparent heart attack.  His bandmates are devastated by the loss of their brother and friend, who was also drumming for Adrenaline Mob at the time of his death.

Mexican lucha libre star Hijo del Perro Aguayo died after a wrestling match injury.  A flying kick from Rey Mysterio led to his collapse;  a delayed medical response and investigation into possible manslaughter followed.  His death caused widespread grief.

An anonymous blackmailer threatened to poison New Zealand infant formula with 1080 poison unless the government ceased its pest control program.  Police launched an investigation, assuring the public that formula remains safe, while the government called the threat "eco-terrorism."

Sigma Alpha Epsilon (SAE) faced severe backlash after a video surfaced showing members singing a racist chant.  The University of Oklahoma expelled SAE, adding to a history of controversies including hazing, alcohol abuse, and sexual misconduct allegations, leading to numerous suspensions and high insurance costs.

DC Comics revamped Superman and Wonder Woman's looks, giving them more casual and armored styles respectively.  Archie Andrews also received a modern makeover to coincide with his upcoming TV show.  These significant redesigns mark a major shift in comic book character appearances.

Pre-election polls incorrectly predicted a tight race between Netanyahu and Herzog.  Netanyahu won decisively, likely due to methodological polling errors, strategic voting, and his late shift to the right, drawing votes from other right-wing parties.

HBO's upcoming documentary, "Montage of Heck," offers an intimate look at Kurt Cobain's life, featuring unseen footage, interviews with loved ones, and an unreleased 12-minute acoustic track.  It premieres May 4th.

US Secretary of State John Kerry says progress has been made in Iran nuclear talks, but significant gaps remain before the March 24 deadline.  A final agreement hinges on Iran proving its nuclear program is solely for peaceful purposes.

Eleven service members, seven Marines and four Louisiana National Guardsmen, died in a Black Hawk helicopter crash.  They were highly decorated veterans with extensive deployments and service, leaving behind families and loved ones.  One recently received the Silver Star.

The White House's classification of the Iran nuclear deal as a non-binding agreement, rather than a treaty requiring Senate approval, is sparking a partisan clash. Republicans argue it's a treaty and accuse the administration of overreach, while the administration defends its actions, citing precedent and the deal's complexity.  The debate hinges on constitutional interpretation and the limits of executive power.

Jeremy Clarkson, Top Gear's host, was suspended by the BBC for allegedly assaulting a producer.  This sparked online petitions both for and against his reinstatement, highlighting his controversial past and the show's immense popularity.  The next few episodes are cancelled pending investigation.

Dolce & Gabbana's Milan fashion show celebrated mothers, showcasing feminine dresses and skirts with rose, lace, and child-like embroidery.  Models even carried children down the runway, creating a heartwarming familial atmosphere.

ISIS released a video showing a 19-year-old Israeli Arab, Mohamed Musallam, being executed by a child.  Israel denies Musallam was a spy; his family says ISIS coerced him, recruiting him with false promises.  The video is another example of ISIS using children for propaganda.

Ferguson's turmoil, sparked by a police shooting and a damning report on racial bias, highlights a national problem: militarized, predominantly white police forces in majority-black communities.  Urgent reforms are needed, including diversifying police departments, curbing military equipment use, and implementing community policing strategies.

Two Chinese men received prison sentences for selling military intelligence, including photos of the Liaoning aircraft carrier, to foreign agents posing as journalists and editors.  One man took photos at a military base, the other provided over 500 carrier images.

Melissa Benoist stars as Supergirl in a new CBS series.  The costume, designed by Colleen Atwood, reflects a modern action hero.  The show features a cast including Calista Flockhart and familiar DC characters, and is executive produced by Greg Berlanti.

Republican senators' letter to Iran and Hillary Clinton's email controversy exacerbated political polarization.  Both sides acted with initially legitimate concerns but made decisions that deepened divisions and hindered progress, demonstrating a failure to learn from past mistakes.

A University of Central Florida team creates 3D-printed electronic prosthetic arms for children with limb differences.  Inspired by a news story, a boy with a missing arm receives one, leading to a nonprofit that has helped numerous children, including Wyatt, embrace their individuality through customized, superhero-themed arms.

The author contrasts their upbringing with their current same-sex partnership, highlighting the persistent gendered division of household labor.  While same-sex couples often achieve better balance, systemic inequities remain, requiring men to actively challenge traditional roles and value household work equally.

Larry David's Broadway debut, "Fish in the Dark," is a box office success but faces criticism for stereotypical portrayal of its Hispanic maid.  Conversely, the National Asian Artists Project cancelled its all-Asian "Show Boat" production due to concerns over cultural appropriation.  The incidents highlight complex issues of representation and casting in theatre.

Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson, reprising their "Zoolander" roles, surprised Paris Fashion Week attendees at the Valentino show, promoting the upcoming "Zoolander 2" film.  Their runway appearance was a highly successful publicity stunt.

A racist video from the University of Oklahoma's Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity led to the expulsion of two students and the fraternity's disbandment.  The university is creating a new vice president position for diversity programs in response.

Jeremy Clarkson, despite accusations of abuse and racism, maintains immense popularity.  His controversies, seemingly calculated, boost his profile and garner fervent fan support, who view criticism as overreactions.  This phenomenon, mirroring other celebrities, highlights the public's fascination with controversial figures.

University President Boren swiftly condemned a racist fraternity video, expelling students and severing ties with the fraternity.  His decisive action, while sparking legal debate, shifted social norms.  Long-term, he should address systemic racism within the university and encourage broader community dialogue on racial inequity.

A Palestinian man rammed his car into Israeli border police and a cyclist in Jerusalem, injuring them.  Police shot and arrested the attacker, whom Hamas praised.  The incident is considered a terror attack, escalating regional tensions.

The National Gallery in London has banned selfie sticks, joining other museums worldwide.  The ban, supported by #MuseumSelfie Day's creator, aims to prevent disruptions and protect artwork and visitors from accidental damage.  Selfie sticks are permitted outside.

Republicans' control of Congress has resulted in a dysfunctional, self-serving governance style.  Their threatened DHS shutdown, prioritizing political gain over national security, exemplifies their reckless disregard for the American people's interests.

Pop star Cody Simpson is promoting the UN's International Day of Happiness by performing at SXSW and contributing to a #HappySoundsLike playlist.  He believes music brings happiness and escape, citing Bob Marley as an inspiration.  He encourages fans to share their happiness-inducing songs online.

At the Gridiron Club Dinner, Obama joked about legalized D.C. marijuana, Hillary Clinton's email server, and birtherism.  Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker also attended, addressing Giuliani's comments about Obama's patriotism.  The event, known for its off-the-record nature, allowed for relaxed humor.

A 1,000-year-old mummified monk statue, stolen from a Chinese temple in 1995, was discovered in the Netherlands.  Chinese authorities are investigating its provenance and seeking its repatriation from a private collector.  The mummy's organs were replaced with paper inscribed with Chinese characters.

Penn State's Kappa Delta Rho fraternity was suspended after allegedly posting compromising photos of women on a private Facebook page.  Police and university officials are investigating, and the university is considering reevaluating its fraternity system.  The incident raises concerns about campus safety and handling of sex crime reports.

The March 25, 2015, CNN Student News covered Afghanistan troop levels, Israeli denials of spying on Iran talks, a French Alps plane crash, and profiled a CNN Hero.  The page also offered a transcript and a "Roll Call" for school mentions.

Parisa Tabriz, Google's "Security Princess,"  works to identify and fix vulnerabilities in Chrome before malicious hackers do.  Her role involves understanding attacker psychology and combating cybercrime, including state-sponsored attacks.  She advocates for more women in tech and uses unconventional training methods.

Serena Williams returned to Indian Wells after a 14-year absence due to racial abuse she and her family faced in 2001.  She received a warm welcome, overcoming emotional nerves to win her first match, viewing her return as a victory in itself.

Chuck Norris' 75th birthday is celebrated with humorous anecdotes highlighting his legendary toughness.  Jokes depict him as unbeatable, even defying time itself.  The article playfully acknowledges the fictional nature of many "Chuck Norris facts."

Serena Williams returns to the Indian Wells tournament after a 14-year boycott stemming from racist abuse and fan suspicion of a rigged match with her sister.  She sought her parents' support before deciding to return, emphasizing forgiveness and strength.

Pi Day (March 14th) is extra special in 2015, aligning with 3.1415.  Celebrations, originating at the Exploratorium 27 years ago, include pie-eating,  and commemorate both pi and Albert Einstein's birthday.

Richard III's remains, discovered under a Leicester car park, revealed details about his life:  he had scoliosis, likely fair hair and blue eyes, a luxurious diet, a roundworm infection, and died from multiple battle wounds, contradicting some historical accounts.

Tom Hanks lip-syncs Carly Rae Jepsen's "I Really Like You" in her new music video.  He's friends with her manager, Scooter Braun, and his appearance, suggested by Hanks himself, is a surprisingly delightful flash mob scene.

A judge ordered the release of photos depicting alleged detainee abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan, rejecting the Defense Department's claim that their release would endanger U.S. personnel.  The government has 60 days to appeal; the ACLU, which filed the lawsuit, believes the photos are crucial evidence.

David Crosby accidentally hit a jogger in Santa Ynez, causing multiple fractures.  The jogger's injuries are not life-threatening.  Crosby, who was not impaired, cooperated with authorities; the sun obscured his view of the jogger.

Coalition airstrikes, at Iraq's request, support Iraqi forces battling ISIS in Tikrit.  The goal is to weaken ISIS strongholds, enabling Iraqi forces to retake the city, a key step towards potentially recapturing Mosul.

Denise Huskins, reported kidnapped from her Bay Area home, was found safe in Huntington Beach.  Police are investigating, considering all possibilities, including whether a ransom was paid.  The FBI is involved.

Former NFL player Darren Sharper pleaded guilty to sexual assault and attempted sexual assault in Arizona, receiving a nine-year prison sentence without parole and lifetime probation.  This resolves one of several cases against him across multiple states.

Germanwings Flight 9525 experienced a rapid, controlled descent before crashing in the Alps.  The recovered black box is crucial.  The lack of a distress call and the descent's speed suggest pilot involvement, though the cause remains unknown, with weather and cockpit events under investigation.

The NIH will admit a second Ebola patient, an American healthcare worker from Sierra Leone, to its Maryland hospital Friday.  This follows the successful treatment of another Ebola patient there last year.  The current Ebola outbreak has killed over 10,000 people.

The VA is restricting veterans' access to community care under the Choice Act, despite congressional intent.  A new bill, S. 207, aims to correct this by mandating the VA utilize its authority to provide necessary care to veterans regardless of proximity to VA facilities.

Angelina Jolie underwent preventative surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes due to a BRCA1 gene mutation,  a decision driven by family history and recent blood test results.  While facing forced menopause, she feels empowered by her choice to minimize cancer risk.

BBC suspended Jeremy Clarkson from "Top Gear" following a physical altercation with a producer.  This follows previous controversies including racist remarks and a diplomatic incident in Argentina.  A petition supporting Clarkson's reinstatement has gained significant traction.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, facing lawsuits alleging insufficient action against scoutmaster sexual abuse, defends its preventative measures.  A key case highlights a scoutmaster's reinstatement despite prior misconduct, prompting debate over responsibility between the church and the Boy Scouts.

J.K. Rowling, responding to a fan questioning Dumbledore's gay portrayal, retorted that gay people simply "look like...people," defending her post-series revelation of the headmaster's sexuality.  Fans largely approved.

Vallejo, California woman Denise Huskins' reported kidnapping was a hoax.  Found unharmed in Huntington Beach, she and her boyfriend refused to cooperate with police, leading to a frustrated investigation and potential charges.  The case wasted significant police resources.

Rohana Rozhan, CEO of Astro Malaysia, a $4.6 billion media company, overcame a challenging upbringing to achieve success.  Known for her independence and drive, she prioritizes meritocracy and female empowerment within her organization, emphasizing hard work and respect.

Jon Hamm, the "Mad Men" star, recently completed a 30-day rehab stint for alcohol abuse.  His representatives confirmed the news, requesting privacy.  This comes shortly before the final season of "Mad Men" premieres.

Creflo Dollar, a prosperity preacher, is fundraising $60 million from his church and supporters to buy a $65 million Gulfstream G650 private jet, citing safety concerns with his older plane.  The jet will facilitate global gospel spreading, according to his ministry.

A new study suggests Neanderthals were more sophisticated than previously thought.  Analysis of 130,000-year-old eagle talons with cut marks indicates Neanderthals created jewelry, demonstrating advanced cognitive abilities and hunting skills.

Two University of Oklahoma students, Parker Rice and Levi Pettit, were expelled for leading a racist fraternity chant containing racial slurs and a lynching reference.  Both have apologized, but their actions sparked widespread condemnation and protests.

An 11-year-old wore a "Fifty Shades of Grey" costume to school.  His mother defended the choice, arguing it was humorous and questioning the school's allowing a teacher's serial killer costume. The school deemed it inappropriate, but allowed participation after a costume change.
A Washington driver used a cardboard cutout of the Dos Equis "Most Interesting Man" to illegally use the HOV lane.  A trooper issued a $124 ticket, praising the driver's creativity.

Severe storms, including at least seven tornadoes, ravaged Oklahoma, killing one and injuring dozens.  A mobile home park and gymnastics studio were heavily damaged near Tulsa.  Governor Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties.  The unusual March storms resulted from a clash of warm and cold air masses.

Republicans, controlling Congress, aim to reverse Obama-era defense cuts, citing growing global threats and insufficient military readiness.  They propose restoring funding to pre-sequestration levels, arguing that underfunding invites conflict and jeopardizes national security.

A massive winter storm, spanning 2,000 miles and impacting 94 million people, caused widespread travel disruptions, power outages, and flooding.  Heavy snowfall led to snow emergencies and school closures, while some areas experienced record-breaking snowfall.

Detroit police discovered the bodies of a teenage girl and an 11-year-old boy in a freezer during an eviction.  Their mother was arrested on child abuse charges, and two older siblings are in protective custody.  The investigation is ongoing.

Putin's 10-day absence fueled health and power speculation.  His reappearance at a meeting in St. Petersburg eased concerns, though his absence coincided with economic turmoil and a postponed meeting.  The Kremlin denied any issues, attributing the rumors to nervousness and media sensationalism.

Jupiter's migration toward the sun, then outward, likely destroyed earlier "super-Earths" and cleared the path for the formation of our inner, smaller planets.  This explains our solar system's unique structure compared to others.

Two Illinois cousins, one an Army National Guard member, were arrested for plotting to support ISIS.  One planned to join ISIS in Egypt, the other to attack a US military base.  This is part of a larger trend of Westerners joining or supporting ISIS.

Jeremy Clarkson, a Top Gear host, faced backlash for his show's Argentina trip (car's license plate referencing the Falklands War) and a history of offensive comments, leading to his suspension from the BBC.  His controversial remarks often target minorities and regions, fueling public outrage.

Two biographies of Steve Jobs offer contrasting portraits.  Isaacson's depicts a cruel genius, while Schlender and Tetzeli's presents a kinder, later-life Jobs, a view endorsed by Apple executives who criticize Isaacson's work as unfair.  The new book includes anecdotes about Jobs' final days and offers a more nuanced perspective, though reviews are mixed.

Taraji P. Henson apologized for falsely accusing Glendale police of racially profiling her son during a traffic stop.  Dashcam footage contradicted her son's claims, revealing he possessed marijuana and other contraband.  Henson retracted her statements and thanked the officer for his kindness.

CNN answered viewer questions about Germanwings Flight 9525, addressing the descent rate, lack of crash prevention technology, absence of live cameras, hacking possibilities, lack of explosion on impact, and pilot drug screening procedures.

Wales, led by Gareth Bale's two goals, defeated Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualifying, topping their group.  Italy and Czech Republic escaped defeats against Bulgaria and Latvia, respectively, while Iceland won convincingly.

Wait A Little horse safaris in South Africa offers unique game reserve tours on horseback, primarily using retrained racehorses.  While potentially dangerous, the well-trained horses and experienced guides ensure a safe, thrilling experience closer to wildlife than traditional safaris.

Nigeria's military reclaimed Gwoza, Boko Haram's self-proclaimed caliphate headquarters, before the country's elections.  This victory, though celebrated by the government, comes amidst ongoing human rights concerns regarding both Boko Haram's atrocities and alleged abuses by Nigerian security forces.

Post-election protests and violence erupted in Rivers State, Nigeria, fueled by allegations of election rigging.  Both leading candidates, Jonathan and Buhari, appealed for calm despite fears of widespread unrest mirroring the deadly 2011 post-election violence.  The election's legitimacy hangs in the balance.

Italy's high court definitively acquitted Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito of Meredith Kercher's murder.  The Kercher family is disappointed and may appeal to the European Court of Human Rights.  Knox and Sollecito may sue Italy for wrongful imprisonment, though their chances vary due to prior statements to investigators.

Cyclone Pam, one of the strongest storms ever recorded, devastated Vanuatu, leaving thousands homeless and causing widespread destruction.  The death toll is rising, and the full extent of the damage, particularly on outer islands, remains unknown.  International aid is arriving, but recovery will take years.

A bipartisan criminal justice reform summit unites unlikely allies—from Newt Gingrich to Eric Holder—driven by shared concerns about mass incarceration's cost and injustice.  Despite differing views on other issues,  both conservatives (emphasizing liberty) and progressives (emphasizing justice) find common ground in reforming the system.
Zayn Malik left One Direction, breaking fans' hearts worldwide.  The remaining four members will continue as a group.  News of his departure caused a massive surge in One Direction's music streams.

Zayn Malik left One Direction, citing unhappiness and a desire for authenticity.  He apologized to fans but feels his departure is best for him and the band, who will continue as a four-piece.  Malik is reportedly pursuing a solo career.

The first "SPECTRE" trailer shows Bond investigating a cryptic message, leading him to confront the terrorist organization SPECTRE.  The trailer hints at a personal connection to the organization, picking up after the destruction of MI6 in "Skyfall."  New cast members join Craig in Sam Mendes' sequel, releasing November 6th.

Putin's recent absence sparked intense online speculation about his health and whereabouts, highlighting Russia's personality-cult political system and raising concerns about a potential power vacuum upon his demise.  The Kremlin's attempts to quell rumors underscore the fragility of its image-dependent regime.

A Charlottesville police investigation found no evidence supporting a Rolling Stone article alleging a University of Virginia student was gang-raped at a fraternity house.  Rolling Stone apologized for inaccuracies and is conducting an internal review.  The lack of evidence doesn't negate the possibility of an incident, but casts doubt on the article's account.

Kylie Minogue will perform a 90-minute show at the Dubai World Cup, a horse racing event with $30 million in prize money.  The multi-talented star is excited to perform at this prestigious event, combining her passion for music with her Australian upbringing's connection to horse racing.

Thousands protested terrorism in Tunis, two weeks after the Bardo Museum attack claimed over 20 lives.  President Essebsi and world leaders joined the "Je suis Bardo" demonstration, following the killing of a key suspect in a raid.  The protest showed Tunisian unity against terrorism.

Richard III's remains, discovered under a Leicester car park, will be reburied next week in a coffin crafted by a distant relative whose DNA helped identify the king.  The reburial includes a procession and ceremonies aiming to correct historical injustices and revise his negative image.

Senator Harry Reid's retirement paves the way for Chuck Schumer's likely ascension to Senate Democratic leader.  Despite progressive opposition, Schumer's extensive political experience, fundraising prowess, and broad network position him favorably for the role.

Seven college students were critically wounded in a Panama City Beach spring break shooting.  A suspect was arrested on attempted murder charges.  The chaotic scene involved multiple agencies and prompted a council meeting addressing escalating violence, though an alcohol ban was rejected.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 aboard.  The cause is unknown, but one black box has been recovered.  Many victims were German students and teachers.  The crash site is difficult to access, hindering recovery efforts.

AMC's "The Walking Dead" prequel spin-off, officially titled "Fear the Walking Dead," will premiere late summer 2015.  Set in Los Angeles during the zombie outbreak's beginning, it features new characters and storylines, with a second season already confirmed for 2016.

Kentucky dominated West Virginia, advancing to the Elite Eight with a 37-0 record.  Notre Dame, Wisconsin, and Arizona also won their games, setting up Elite Eight matchups.  Arizona will face Wisconsin in a rematch of last year's game.

Lewis Hamilton secured pole position for the Malaysian Grand Prix, beating Sebastian Vettel and teammate Nico Rosberg in qualifying despite torrential rain.  Rosberg was disappointed with third, while Verstappen impressed with sixth place.  Hamilton aims to follow his Australian win.

Facing Houthi rebels, Yemeni President Hadi secured a coalition airstrike from Sunni Arab nations, led by Saudi Arabia, against the Shiite Houthis, whom Saudi Arabia views as Iranian proxies.  The intervention, supported logistically by the US, has caused civilian casualties and media crackdowns.

A commuter train derailed in Los Angeles after colliding with a car, injuring 21 people (two critically).  The accident, near USC, caused traffic concerns for a nearby soccer game, prompting shuttle bus deployment.

Germanwings Flight 9525 crashed in the Alps due to the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, intentionally manipulating the plane's controls during the captain's absence.  The descent was steady, but ultimately fatal for all 150 on board.

Jeremy Clarkson's suspension from "Top Gear" sparked a near-million-signature petition for his reinstatement, delivered via tank.  An investigation is underway, with Clarkson's future uncertain despite support from fans and Prime Minister Cameron.  His controversial past adds to the ongoing saga.

The Montoursville community, having lost 21 in TWA Flight 800, offers condolences to Haltern am See after the Germanwings crash.  They share their experience of grief, community support, and long-term healing, hoping it helps.

The Germanwings crash revealed the unsettling truth that pilots, despite their perceived professionalism, are human and fallible.  Lubitz's premeditated act shattered the illusion of pilots as infallible, highlighting the unpredictable nature of the human mind.

The March 30, 2015, CNN Student News covered Nigerian elections, an astronaut becoming a research subject on the ISS, and a new fire-extinguishing sound wave invention.  The segment also included a school roll call feature.

Manchester United's 3-0 victory over Tottenham boosted their Champions League hopes, while Chelsea's draw with Southampton extended their EPL lead.  Real Madrid beat Levante 2-0, with Bale scoring both goals.  Rooney's playful goal celebration was a highlight.

Thousands mourned Singapore's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, at a state funeral attended by global dignitaries.  His death prompted widespread grief and tributes, celebrating his economic achievements while acknowledging criticisms of his authoritarian rule.

Houthi rebels seized Taiz airport, escalating Yemen's conflict.  The UN warns of imminent civil war as violence increases, including a deadly mosque bombing claimed by ISIS, prompting the US to withdraw personnel.  President Hadi's legitimacy is disputed.

A video surfaced of a fraternity's house mother repeatedly using a racial slur while singing along to a song.  Despite the offensive content, two Black alumni defended her, citing her long history of kindness and claiming it was a lapse in judgment.  The incident followed a racist chant by fraternity members, leading to the chapter's closure and student expulsions.

South Carolina Aquarium rescued a rare, 475-pound juvenile leatherback sea turtle, a potentially only the fifth such US rescue.  Found hypoglycemic but improving, it will likely be released back into the ocean soon.

ISIS claimed responsibility for a deadly attack at Tunis' Bardo Museum, killing 23, mostly foreign tourists.  The attack, possibly by local ISIS affiliates, targeted Tunisia's tourism sector and raises concerns about the country's stability despite its democratic progress.

Intense Iran nuclear talks face a Tuesday deadline.  Key disagreements remain on limiting Iranian advanced centrifuge research and the pace of UN sanctions lifting.  While some progress is reported,  Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu warns the emerging deal is worse than feared.  A framework agreement is the immediate goal.

A jury found Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams liable for copyright infringement of Marvin Gaye's "Got to Give It Up" with their song "Blurred Lines," awarding the Gaye family over $7 million in damages.  The verdict sets a precedent for music copyright cases.

Over half the world's population now lives in cities, a trend projected to increase.  African cities, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, are experiencing rapid growth and attracting investment, though North African cities currently hold stronger rankings due to existing infrastructure.  Competition for economic dominance is intensifying.

Trevor Noah will replace Jon Stewart as host of "The Daily Show."  Stewart, who departs after 16 years, approves of Noah, a 31-year-old South African comedian.  The show, known for its satirical news coverage, has launched successful spin-offs and careers.

In Lagos, Nigeria, "free readers" gather at newspaper stands, engaging in lively political and social discussions.  While technically not free, a nominal fee is sometimes charged.  These groups, though declining due to internet access and economic hardship, foster community and even job opportunities.

India's Supreme Court struck down Section 66A of the IT Act, deeming its vague wording unconstitutional and a violation of free speech.  The law allowed arrests for offensive online content, sparking debate over censorship.

Three Southern California school owners were arrested for a "pay-to-stay" scheme, defrauding the immigration system by enrolling 1,500 foreign students who never attended classes, generating $6 million annually.  The schools provided fraudulent I-20 forms for student visas.

Before her maternity leave, the Duchess of Cambridge made her final public appearances, visiting the Stephen Lawrence Centre and a youth charity.  She's expecting her second child in mid-to-late April.

The Germanwings Flight 9525 crash highlights the critical role of pilot mental health.  The co-pilot's deliberate actions underscore the need for more rigorous and frequent psychological screenings for pilots, despite the inherent unpredictability of human behavior.

Sam Taylor-Johnson will not direct the "Fifty Shades" sequels due to creative differences with author E L James, who will write the screenplay for "Fifty Shades Darker."  Despite the first film's box office success,  a new director will helm the next installments.

Despite a recent dislocated shoulder from a fall, 85-year-old Arnold Palmer plans to hit the ceremonial opening tee shot at the Masters, joining Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player on April 9th, even without current doctor's permission to swing a club.

Negotiations for a nuclear deal with Iran are nearing a deadline.  While progress has been made, key disagreements remain, particularly regarding sanctions relief and the number of Iranian centrifuges.  Both Iranian and US officials express cautious optimism, but significant hurdles persist.

Millions of Chinese children are left behind by parents migrating to cities for work, leading to significant social and developmental problems.  The restrictive *hukou* system exacerbates this issue by limiting access to urban services and education.  While reforms are discussed, the consequences for these children remain severe.

Afghan President Ghani's Washington visit precedes potential Taliban peace talks, but success is unlikely due to the Taliban's strong position and the Afghan government's weakness.  The US should slow troop withdrawal and support the Afghan government's legitimacy to improve future negotiation prospects.

Iraqi forces, aided by Shia militias and US airstrikes, have made significant gains in Tikrit, capturing key areas and raising the Iraqi flag.  Despite IED challenges and previous setbacks, this offensive marks a renewed push to retake the city from ISIS.

Hillary Clinton's email controversy is the latest in a long line of scandals.  Her likely response, based on past experience, involves counter-attacking accusers, weathering the storm, and rallying her party base.  Her resilience makes predicting her demise premature.

Swedish prosecutors, facing a statute of limitations, will interview Julian Assange in London and take his DNA, a request his lawyer views positively.  This follows years of Assange's refusal to leave the Ecuadorian embassy, fearing US extradition.

New Zealand won a thrilling World Cup semifinal against South Africa, reaching their first-ever final thanks to Grant Elliott's last-ball six.  Rain interrupted the match, but New Zealand chased down the revised target of 298, securing a historic victory.

Young Chinese, seeking solace in a competitive society, are increasingly turning to Buddhism, particularly the Tibetan branch.  While some embrace it fully, many integrate Buddhist practices into their lives, viewing it more as a cultural influence than a strict religion.

A suicide truck bomb attack on an Egyptian security forces camp in Al-Arish, North Sinai, killed a civilian and injured 44 others.  The driver was also killed.  The attack follows a recent surge in militant activity in the region.

Al-Shabaab militants attacked government offices in Baidoa, Somalia, killing nine including four attackers.  A car bomb and gunfire ensued.  Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility, while the African Union condemned the attack, viewing it as a desperate act following recent defeats.

Eugenie Bouchard and Justin Bieber played tennis doubles at a charity event.  Bouchard tweeted about Bieber's "nice serve," fulfilling a past playful wish for a date with him.  Caroline Wozniacki also interacted with Bieber at the event.

Iran nuclear negotiations progress despite Israeli opposition.  While Israel possesses the military capability to strike Iran,  a post-deal attack is deemed implausible due to severe potential consequences: international condemnation, jeopardized alliances, and regional escalation.

Kenya is a major cut flower exporter, particularly roses, benefiting from its climate and transport links.  The industry employs hundreds of thousands, though environmental concerns exist.  While Europe is the main market, Kenya is diversifying globally and assisting other African nations like Rwanda to develop their flower industries.
Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted SNL,  memorably portraying Bambi and "The Rock Obama."  He then surprised Wrestlemania 31 fans with a  team-up with Ronda Rousey against WWE executives.
The Vatican hosted 150 homeless people on a special tour, including the Vatican Museums and Sistine Chapel, organized by the Office of Papal Charities to showcase the Vatican's artistic patrimony.

The UK Supreme Court ruled to release Prince Charles' previously secret letters to government officials, ending a decade-long legal battle.  The Guardian fought for their release, arguing the letters show potential political meddling, while the government and Prince Charles cited privacy concerns.

The author revisits Kipling's "Jungle Book," reflecting on human-tiger conflict in India.  While tiger poaching is a threat, human-wildlife conflict due to habitat encroachment poses a greater challenge.  Despite a recent increase in tiger numbers, the growing human population threatens their future.

Indiana's Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) sparked backlash due to fears of LGBT discrimination.  While the governor initially defended the law, pressure led to calls for a "fix."  Options include statewide LGBT anti-discrimination laws (unlikely) or amending the RFRA to respect existing local ordinances, a solution likely opposed by RFRA supporters.

Jordan Spieth won the Valspar Championship, becoming only the fourth player since 1940 to win twice on the PGA Tour before 22.  He's now focused on overtaking Rory McIlroy for the world's No. 1 ranking.

The April 1, 2015, CNN Student News covered global events (Nigeria, Switzerland, West Africa), U.S. wages impacting the economy, and the potential of cyborg cockroaches for rescue missions.  The show also included a transcript and a "Roll Call" segment for student participation.

Lewis Hamilton won the season-opening Australian Grand Prix, leading a Mercedes 1-2 finish.  Sebastian Vettel took third for Ferrari.  Several drivers retired, highlighting Mercedes' dominance and a disappointing race for other teams.  Hamilton playfully interacted with Arnold Schwarzenegger on the podium.

Michael Douglas recounts his son Dylan's experience with anti-Semitism in Southern Europe.  This prompted Douglas to write an opinion piece urging everyone to actively combat rising anti-Semitism, which he sees fueled by various societal factors.

Researchers recreated a 1000-year-old Anglo-Saxon eye salve recipe, finding it highly effective against MRSA, a drug-resistant superbug.  The salve, containing garlic, onion/leek, wine, and oxgall, killed up to 90% of MRSA in lab and animal tests, potentially revolutionizing antibiotic treatment.

Netanyahu's pre-election denial of a Palestinian state, though retracted, damaged US-Israel and Israeli-Palestinian relations.  Palestinians distrust Netanyahu, may seek UN recognition, and the US will reassess its relationship with Israel, jeopardizing future peace talks.

Indiana's new religious freedom law, allowing businesses to refuse service based on religious beliefs, sparked a social media firestorm.  Supporters cite religious freedom; opponents call it discrimination.  A boycott is underway, but some Indiana businesses reject discrimination.

London's Fourth Plinth features Hans Haacke's "Gift Horse," a skeletal horse with a stock ticker, commenting on power, money, and history.  Reactions are mixed, with some finding it confusing and others appreciating its wit and artistic merit.
Adam West and Burt Ward hinted at voicing Batman and Robin in a new 90-minute animated film celebrating the 1960s TV series' 50th anniversary in 2016.  Warner Bros. hasn't confirmed the project.

Negotiations on a framework agreement for Iran's nuclear program were extended to Wednesday.  While progress was made, disagreements remain on sanctions relief, Iran's nuclear advancements, and the handling of its fissile material.  A final deal is still uncertain.

Following Jeremy Clarkson's firing from "Top Gear," BBC director-general Tony Hall received death threats via email from an unknown source outside the UK.  Police are investigating, and the BBC declined comment on security matters.

Julianne Moore's Oscar win for "Still Alice" highlights the urgent need to address Alzheimer's, disproportionately affecting women.  The author launches "Wipe Out Alzheimer's," a women-led campaign to fund research, raise awareness, and advocate for increased government funding.
A Canadian tourist, Jennifer Karren, died after a whale collision with a small inflatable tour boat off Cabo San Lucas.  Two others were injured.  The incident is under investigation.

Ivory Coast's Simone Gbagbo received a 20-year prison sentence for crimes against humanity stemming from 2010 post-election violence.  Her husband, Laurent Gbagbo, awaits trial at the ICC for similar charges.  Both deny the accusations.

Rory McIlroy, after throwing his 3-iron into a lake, had it retrieved by Trump.  Trump returned it, but McIlroy again hit it into the water.  Despite this,  Dustin Johnson won the tournament after a six-month break, celebrating with his family.
references:

The 20th MLS season begins this weekend .

Bafetimbi Gomis collapses within 10 minutes of kickoff at Tottenham .
But he reportedly left the pitch conscious and wearing an oxygen mask .
Gomis later said that he was "feeling well"
The incident came three years after Fabrice Muamba collapsed at White Hart Lane .

Rory McIlroy throws club into water at WGC Cadillac Championship .
Northern Irishman frustrated after pulling shot into water hazard .

Cayman Naib, 13, hasn't been heard from since Wednesday .
Police, family, volunteers search for eighth-grader .

Ruben Navarrette: Schilling deserves praise for taking on online haters for offensive comments about his daughter .
Navarrette: In protecting his child, Schilling set a model for parenting and taught us a lesson about social media .

Two American women arrested for carving initials into a Colosseum wall .

Cambodia's Angkor Archeological Park experienced a string of nudity-related incidents this year .

It will be a first time for the tour stateside .
First show will be in Louisville, Kentucky .

A jihadist group claims responsibility in an audio recording, news agency reports .
The Malian government calls the shooting a "terrorist act"
One French citizen, one Belgian and three Malians are killed .

Alleged incident happened in match at St James' Park .
Players face six-match ban if found guilty .
Evans denied spitting in statement .
Cisse statement says: "I let you down"

The abducted workers were seized in an attack on an oil field last week .
They are from the Philippines, Bangladesh, Austria, the Czech Republic and Ghana .
Militants have carried out a series of attacks on oil fields in recent weeks .

Wichita, Kansas, high school students surprise principal with kind-hearted senior prank .
"This is why I do the things that I do," the principal says .

Comic book artist Norman Lee went missing in the Cayman Islands on Thursday .
Authorities called off search on Friday evening .

Use the Transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary .
At the bottom of the page, comment for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News.  You must be a teacher or a student age 13 or older to request a mention on the CNN Student News Roll Call.

Jeff Goldblum set to reprise his role in "Independence Day 2"
Liam Hemsworth and Jessie Usher also cast in key roles .
Sequel will be released 20 years after the original box office smash about an alien invasion .

Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic on Saturday, hospital spokeswoman said .
The former vice president, 87, was treated for cold and flu symptoms .

A man in suburban Boston is selling snow online to customers in warmer states .
For $89, he will ship 6 pounds of snow in an insulated Styrofoam box .

Jina Krause-Vilmar: On International Women's Day, focus on helping refugee women adapt to new lives .
She says aid agencies like hers aim to help these women build job skills and financial literacy .
She says the effort includes educating men about wives' and daughters' new roles .

Real Madrid slump to defeat against Athletic Bilbao .
Solitary goal from Aritz Aduriz enough to give the Basques victory .
Bayern Munich continue Bundesliga domination .

Police in Japan say they have arrested a man, 40, after five neighbors were fatally stabbed .
The accused shares the same surname as the victims, aged 59 to 84, local media say .
A police official says the man has admitted to the stabbings but refused to comment further .
Car bomb detonated near police vehicle in Lashkar Gah, deputy governor says .

The terror attacks in India left more than 160 people dead .
A  court granted the suspect bail last year .

Police: Officer fired two shots when the man charged at him .
The case was immediately turned over to the GBI .

A photo of a green woodpecker flying with a weasel on its back has gone viral on Twitter .
The image was snapped by amateur photographer Martin Le-May near London .
It sparked the hashtag #weaselpecker and has spawned numerous memes .

A wag decided to sell "air from Kanye West concert" on eBay .
Bidding got to more than $60,000 before plug was pulled .
Others are now doing similar auctions .

Delta Air Lines Flight 1086 skidded into a fence last week at a LaGuardia Airport beset by winter weather .
The NTSB says the crew reported they did not sense any deceleration from the wheel brake upon landing .

More than 100 schools renamed in honor of students killed in a Taliban schoolhouse attack .
A six-hour siege at a Peshawar school killed 145 people in December .

#thedress was an Internet sensation: Is it blue and black or white and gold?
The Salvation Army in South Africa is using it to raise awareness .
The reaction has been mostly positive .

The lack of charges against Busch expedited the decision, a NASCAR official says .
Kurt Busch was accused of grabbing his ex-girlfriend by the throat, slamming her head .
He twice appealed NASCAR's indefinite suspension and lost .

Interim report exposes delays and inaction after MH370 disappeared .
Flight carrying 239 people and crew has not been found, one year later .
Took 10 hours for the first search flights to take off, according to report .

167 people have been rescued, Myanmar's government says .
The ferry capsized after being hit by a large wave in bad weather conditions .

China sends fighter jets to patrol over border with Myanmar following the incident .
Report: In addition to the fatalities, nine others were wounded .

According to a Pew report, 80% of Internet users have looked up health info online .
Sites like Mayo Clinic and others curated by doctors are safer than online forums .

Erich Nowsch will face three charges, including first-degree murder .
He is accused of killing Tammy Meyers in front of her home .
The two lived withing walking distance of each other .

Latest Ferguson shootings push strained race relations to breaking point .
Donna Brazile: Relationship between police forces and minority communities must improve .

North Korea apologizes to Bangladesh after one of embassy's diplomat caught with 59 pounds of gold .
Gold was undeclared, says Bangladeshi government .

Baby Lily was trapped in the car in the cold river for as long as 14 hours .
"She knows everything she knew before anything happened. It's amazing," father says .
Lily's mother, Lynn Jennifer Groesbeck, died in the crash .

The chopper was registered to an air ambulance company .
It was en route from Tulsa to McAlester .

A Californian startup has developed a circular smartphone called "Runcible"
The provocative anti-phone is meant to be an antidote to our obsession for digital devices .

Official "Star Wars" universe gets its first gay character, a lesbian governor .
The character appears in the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith"
Characters in "Star Wars" movies have gradually become more diverse .

The Pakistani Taliban claims responsibility for the suicide bombings .
At least 78 people were wounded in the attack, hospital official says .

IRS scam has swindled victims out of more than $15 million since 2013 .
Scammers warn of seizing property, prison time .
FTC and Treasury department have open investigations .

Timothy Stanley: GOP senators' letter to Iranian leaders seems extraordinary .
